awd_titl_txt: Science, civilization, and the origins of European sinology
awd_abstract_narration:
Summary

 Science, civilization, and the origins of European sinology examines the emergence of European scholarship on Chinese science and civilization through the prism of a controversy over the Passion Eclipse, a debate born in the shadows that, according to the synoptic gospels, covered the land until Jesus spoke his last words.  Some seventeen centuries later, a Jesuit missionary shockingly suggested that the pagan Chinese might shed light on an event at the very heart of Christian belief, for their historical records for the same year and month as the crucifixion told of a solar eclipse that had occurred against the natural course of the stars. In response, citizens of the early modern Republic of Letters gradually computed and conjectured their way to increasingly sophisticated evaluations of China's scientific traditions. The project will use the Chinese Passion Eclipse controversy as a window into the ways in which early modern European scholars confronted Chinese natural knowledge.

Intellectual merit

Mapping the correspondence networks of the central participants in the Chinese Passion Eclipse controversy will provide a fresh perspective into the formation of sinological communities in early modern Europe, one that emphasizes dynamics of intellectual sociability over confessional divides or a nascent orientalism.  The project also builds on recent studies of reading, collecting, and scientific practices to examine how these scholars applied a variety of interpretive tools to dissect claims concerning Chinese science's venerable antiquity and to construct narratives about its perceived stagnation.  And in moving beyond sinophilic and sinophobic labels, the project advances a fine-grained approach to processes of cultural exchange in the history of science by drawing on recent work in manuscript and print culture to analyze texts as material artifacts that make tangible complex histories of knowledge production and reception.

Broader impacts

The project will provide researchers, educators, students, and broad readerships with a methodologically and pedagogically innovative model for historical studies of cross-cultural scientific exchange.  Plans for disseminating the project's results include a monograph addressed to specialist and general audiences and a contribution to an American Historical Association publication series that makes issues in world history accessible to students and educators at the secondary and post-secondary levels.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined how early modern European scholars applied a variety of interpretive tools to dissect claims concerning Chinese science?s venerable antiquity and to construct narratives about its perceived stagnation. It did so by taking a perspective on the formation of sinological communities in early modern Europe that emphasizes dynamics of intellectual sociability over confessional divides or a nascent orientalism. In moving beyond sinophilic and sinophobic labels, the project advanced a fine-grained approach to processes of cultural exchange in the history of science by analyzing texts as material artifacts that make tangible complex histories of knowledge production and reception.

This research project found that early modern European conceptions of Chinese astronomy?long understood by scholars as informed by Christian concerns with Biblical chronology and missionary priorities?were also mediated by at least two distinct methodological approaches. One approach was prescriptive, drawing on contemporary astronomical theories to retrodict historical observations and so evaluate Chinese astronomical data. The other was descriptive, deploying philological techniques to translate and emend textual evidence for Chinese astronomical work. Further research will focus on the preliminary hypothesis that the convergence of these two approaches can help explain the particular contours of early modern European scholarship on Chinese science and civilization.

The analysis of textual artifacts (notebooks, letters, annotations in printed works, tabular formats) using research conducted for this project should provide new insight into construction of the early modern European sinological archive. Development of methods for reconstructing and analyzing astronomical archives using research conducted for this project should be of use to investigators hoping to make contemporary astronomical use of observational data collected in earlier historical periods. The Max-Planck-Institut f?r Wissenschaftsgeschichte (Max Planck Institute for History of Science) and the Observatoire de Paris have agreed to partner on digitizing the correspondence of the eighteenth-century French astronomer Joseph-Nicolas Delisle held at the Observatoire, and to make it publicly available via the Paris Observatory's and MPIWG?s websites should improve scholarly understanding of a significant component of the Observatoire's historical archives, including some of the earliest technically-informed European studies of Chinese astronomical material. 

It has been three decades since Michael Adas wrote in his Machines as the measure of man(1989) of how science and technology came to function for Europeans as the litmus test for judging civilizational superiority and justify political and economic asymmetries. Today, with STEM fields as increasingly contested arenas of investment and interest for both state and non-state actors, their status as markers of civilizational achievement is more salient than ever. By focusing on processes rather than outcomes, methodologies rather than ideologies, this project will provide researchers, educators, students, and broad readerships with some alternative approaches to analyzing the construction and reconstruction of scientific traditions in the crucible of cross-cultural encounter, exchange, and competition.
